This critical field is defined within the range $-1 < \kappa < \pi^2/4$ where it monotonically decreases from $h^{\rm cr}_{\rm kink} = 1$ to zero. For $\kappa = 0$ one recovers $h^{\rm cr}_{\rm kink} = \pi^2/16$ (Ref.~\onlinecite{Bogdanov1994}).  Whereas for larger fields the kink is an excitation of the field-polarized state, the commensurate-incommensurate transition can take place at $h^{\rm cr}_{\rm kink}$, and kinks become energetically preferred resulting in a soliton lattice. However, as the kink is a topological excitation it does not correspond to a local but rather a global instability of the field-polarized state for $h \leq h^{\rm cr}_{\rm kink}$.
